statements.name: PROC SORT
statements.description: Orders SAS data set observations by the values of one or more character or numeric variables.

arguments.name: ASCII
arguments.description: specifies ASCII.

arguments.name: DANISH
arguments.description: specifies Danish.

arguments.name: EBCDIC
arguments.description: specifies EBCDIC.

arguments.name: FINNISH
arguments.description: specifies Finnish.

arguments.name: NATIONAL
arguments.description: specifies a customized sequence.

arguments.name: NORWEGIAN
arguments.description: specifies Norwegian.

arguments.name: REVERSE
arguments.description: reverses the collation order for character variables.

arguments.name: SWEDISH
arguments.description: specifies Swedish.

arguments.name: SORTSEQ=
arguments.description: specifies the collating sequence.

arguments.name: collating-sequence-option
arguments.description: specifies one of the PROC SORT statement collating-sequence-options (ASCII, DANISH, EBCDIC, FINNISH, NORWEGIAN, POLISH, REVERSE, SWEDISH) or a translation table, which can be one that SAS provides or any user-defined translation table. Translation tables provided by SAS are: ASCII, DANISH, EBCDIC, FINNISH, ITALIAN, NORWEGIAN, POLISH, REVERSE, SPANISH, and SWEDISH.

arguments.name: translation_table
arguments.description: specifies one of the PROC SORT statement collating-sequence-options (ASCII, DANISH, EBCDIC, FINNISH, NORWEGIAN, POLISH, REVERSE, SWEDISH) or a translation table, which can be one that SAS provides or any user-defined translation table. Translation tables provided by SAS are: ASCII, DANISH, EBCDIC, FINNISH, ITALIAN, NORWEGIAN, POLISH, REVERSE, SPANISH, and SWEDISH.

arguments.name: encoding-value
arguments.description: specifies an encoding value. The result is the same as a binary collation of the character data represented in the specified encoding. See the supported encoding value in the .

arguments.name: LINGUISTIC
arguments.description: specifies linguistic collation, which sorts characters in a culturally sensitive manner according to rules that are associated with a language and locale. The rules and default collating-sequence options are based on the language that is specified in the current locale setting. The implementation is provided by the International Components for Unicode (ICU) library. It produces results that are largely compatible with the Unicode Collation Algorithms (UCA). For more information, see .

arguments.name: ALTERNATE_HANDLING=
arguments.description: controls the handling of variable characters like spaces, punctuation, and symbols. When this option is not specified (using the default value Non-Ignorable), differences among these variable characters are of the same importance as differences among letters. If the ALTERNATE_HANDLING option is specified, these variable characters are of minor importance.

arguments.name: CASE_FIRST=
arguments.description: specifies the order of uppercase and lowercase letters. This argument is valid for only TERTIARY, QUATERNARY, or IDENTICAL levels. The following table provides the values and information for the CASE_FIRST argument:

arguments.name: COLLATION=
arguments.description: specifies character ordering. The following table lists the available COLLATION= values.

arguments.name: LOCALE=
arguments.description: specifies the locale name in the form of a POSIX name (for example, ja_JP). For a list of locale and POSIX values supported by PROC SORT, see .

arguments.name: NUMERIC_COLLATION=
arguments.description: orders integer values within the text by the numeric value instead of characters used to represent the numbers.

arguments.name: STRENGTH=
arguments.description: The value of strength is related to the collation level. There are five collation-level values. The following table provides information about the five levels. The default value for strength is related to the locale.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set.

arguments.name: DATECOPY
arguments.description: sorts a SAS data set without changing the created and modified dates.

arguments.name: DUPOUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to which duplicate observations are written.

arguments.name: EQUALS
arguments.description: specifies the relative order within BY groups.

arguments.name: FORCE
arguments.description: forces redundant sorting.

arguments.name: NODUPKEY
arguments.description: deletes observations with duplicate BY values.

arguments.name: NOEQUALS
arguments.description: does not maintain relative order within BY groups.

arguments.name: NOTHREADS
arguments.description: prevents threaded sorting.

arguments.name: NOUNIQUEKEY
arguments.description: eliminates observations from the output data set that have a unique sort key.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set.

arguments.name: OVERWRITE
arguments.description: deletes the input data set before the replacement output data set is populated.

arguments.name: PRESORTED
arguments.description: specifies whether the data set is likely already sorted.

arguments.name: SORTSIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the available memory.

arguments.name: MAX
arguments.description: specifies that all available memory can be used.

arguments.name: n
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in bytes, where n is a real number.

arguments.name: K
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in kilobytes, where n is a real number.

arguments.name: M
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in megabytes, where n is a real number.

arguments.name: G
arguments.description: specifies the amount of memory in gigabytes, where n is a real number.

arguments.name: TAGSORT
arguments.description: reduces temporary disk usage.

arguments.name: THREADS
arguments.description: enables or prevents the activation of threaded sorting.

arguments.name: UNIQUEOUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set for eliminated observations.

statements.name: ATTRIB
statements.description: Associates a format, informat, label, and length with one or more variables.

arguments.name: variable-list
arguments.description: names the variables that you want to associate with the attributes.

arguments.name: FORMAT=
arguments.description: associates a format with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: INFORMAT=
arguments.description: associates an informat with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: associates a label with variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: LENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the length of variables in variable-list.

arguments.name: TRANSCODE=
arguments.description: specifies whether character variables can be transcoded. Use TRANSCODE=NO to suppress transcoding. Variables with TRANSCODE=NO are not returned.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable by which PROC SORT sorts the observations. PROC SORT first arranges the data set by the values in ascending order, by default, of the first BY variable. PROC SORT then arranges any observations that have the same value of the first BY variable by the values of the second BY variable in ascending order. This sorting continues for every specified BY variable.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: reverses the sort order for the variable that immediately follows in the statement so that observations are sorted from the largest value to the smallest value. The DESCENDING keyword modifies the variable that follows it.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: names one or more variables for SAS to associate with a format. You must specify at least one variable.

arguments.name: format
arguments.description: specifies the format that is listed for writing the values of the variables.

statements.name: KEY
statements.description: Specifies sorting keys and variables. The KEY statement is an alternative to the BY statement. The KEY statement syntax allows for the future possibility of specifying different collation options for each KEY variable. Currently, the only options allowed are ASCENDING and DESCENDING.

arguments.name: variable
arguments.description: specifies the variable by which PROC SORT orders the observations. Multiple variables can be specified. Each of these variables must be separated by a space. A range of variables can also be specified. For example, the following code shows how to specify multiple variables and a range of variables:

arguments.name: ASCENDING
arguments.description: sorts in ascending order the variable or variables that it follows. Observations are sorted from the smallest value to the largest value. The ASCENDING keyword modifies all the variables that precede it in the KEY statement.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: reverses the sort order for the variable that it follows in the statement so that observations are sorted from the largest value to the smallest value. The DESCENDING keyword modifies all the variables that it precedes in the KEY statement.

arguments.name: text-string
arguments.description: specifies a label of up to 256 bytes.
removes a label from a variable. Enclose a single blank space in quotation marks to remove an existing label. You can remove labels from multiple variables in a single LABEL statement:

statements.name: WHERE
statements.description: Subsets the input data set by specifying certain conditions that each observation must meet before it is available for processing.

arguments.name: where-expression
arguments.description: is an arithmetic or logical expression that generally consists of a sequence of operands and operators.

arguments.name: logical-operator
arguments.description: can be AND, AND NOT, OR, or OR NOT.
